verses.verse: And Balaam saw that it pleased Jehovah to bless Israel, and he did not go, as at other times, to seek spells. And he set his face toward the wilderness.
And Balaam lifted up his eyes and saw Israel camping, by its tribes. And the Spirit of God was on him.
And he took up his parable and said, The statement of Balaam the son of Beor, and the saying of the man whose eyes have been opened;
the statement of him who hears the words of God, who sees the vision of the Almighty, fallen down, yet with open eyes:
How good are your tents, O Jacob, your dwellings, O Israel!
They are spread out like valleys, like gardens by a river; and Jehovah has planted aloes, as cedars beside the water.
He makes water flow from his buckets, and his seed shall be in many waters; his king shall be higher than Agag, and his kingdom exalted.

God who has brought him out of Egypt is for him like the lofty horns of the wild ox for him, he shall eat up the nations, adversaries to him, and he shall break their bones in pieces, and shall pierce them through with his arrows.
He has crouched; he has lain down like a lion, and like a lioness; who shall rouse him up? Blessed is everyone that blesses you, and cursed is everyone that curses you.

And Balak's anger was hot against Balaam, and he struck his palms together. And Balak said to Balaam, I called you to curse my enemies; and, behold, you have altogether blessed them these three times.
And now, flee to your place. I said to honor you with great honor, but, behold, Jehovah has kept you back from honor.
And Balaam said to Balak, Did I not speak to your messengers that you sent to me, saying,
If Balak would give me his house full of silver and gold, I cannot go beyond the mouth of Jehovah, to do good or bad of my own heart. What Jehovah speaks, that I will speak.
And now, behold, I go to my people. Come, and I will counsel you what this people shall do to your people in the latter days.
And he took up his parable and said, The statement of Balaam the son of Beor, and the statement of the man whose eyes are opened;
the statement of him who hears the words of God, and he knowing the knowledge of the Most High, who sees the vision of the Almighty, falling down, yet with open eyes:

I shall see him, but not now; I shall behold him, but not near. A star marches out of Jacob, and a scepter shall rise out of Israel and shall dash the corners of Moab, and tear down all the sons of tumult.
And Edom shall be a possession; and Seir shall be a possession, for his enemies, but Israel shall do mightily.
And one out of Jacob shall rule, and will destroy the survivors from Ar.
And he looked upon Amalek, and took up his parable and said, Amalek was the first of the nations, but his latter end is to destruction forever.
And he looked upon the Kenites, and took up his parable, and said, Your dwelling- place may be enduring, and your nest may be set in a rock,
but the Kenites shall be consumed, until Assyria shall carry you away.
And he took up his parable and said, Alas! Who shall live when God puts out?
And ships shall come from the coast of Cyprus, and they shall humble Assyria, and they shall humble Eber, and he also shall come to destruction forever.
And Balaam rose up and left, and returned to his place; and Balak also went on his way.
